title: Boeing accused of supplying 'flying coffins' by US lawmakers
text:
Boeing has been accused of supplying 'flying coffins' by US lawmakers, in a grilling over the deadly 737 Max 8 plane crashes.

Quizzing Boeing chief executive Dennis Muilenburg, senators accused it of deliberate concealment.

Defective: The Senate commerce committee said it had serious concerns that Boeing put profits before safety in the 737 Max 8s

The Senate commerce committee said it had serious concerns that Boeing put profits before safety, as it sought approval to get the 737s aircraft back in the air.

The planes' anti-stall software was found to contain defects that forced planes to point downwards if it sensed that the craft might stall.

A total of 346 people died in two crashes, one last October in Indonesia and the other in Ethiopia in March. All 737 Max 8s were grounded after the latter crash.

Democratic senator Richard Blumenthal said Boeing supplied 'flying coffins' by concealing the anti-stall software from pilots, saying it was mentioned just once in the 1,600-page pilot manual.

Muilenburg said he was 'heartbroken' by the fatalities. The committee also looked at internal messages, which Boeing had not originally handed to investigators. In them, chief test pilot Mark Forkner said the software was erratic in 2016.

Republican senator Ted Cruz asked: 'What does that say about Boeing? Why did you not act before 346 people died?'
